H0.text: Color is the property of a mineral that is most likely being tested when the mineral is scratched with a nail.

H1.text: Hardness is the property of a mineral most likely being tested when it is scratched with a nail.

H2.text: Cleavage is the property of a mineral most likely being tested when it is scratched with a nail.

H3.text: Luster is the property of a mineral that is most likely being tested when it is scratched with a nail.

A4.text: The Mohs scale of mineral hardness is a qualitative ordinal scale, from 1 to 10, characterizing scratch resistance of minerals through the ability of harder material to scratch softer material.

A5.text: The method of comparing hardness by observing which minerals can scratch others is of great antiquity, having been mentioned by Theophrastus in his treatise On Stones, c. 300 BC, followed by Pliny the Elder in his Naturalis Historia, c. AD 77.
